bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. ARRINGTON:H.R. 7391.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I Section 8[Page H10587]

item.text: Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, and in addition to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, and in addition to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

item.name: Emergency medical services and trauma care

item.text:
Rural Hospital Freedom and Flexibility Act of 2018

This bill establishes several requirements under Medicare regarding certified rural emergency access centers, including payment, certification, and participation requirements.
item.name: Introduced in House

bill.title: Rural Hospital Freedom and Flexibility Act of 2018

item.title: Rural Hospital Freedom and Flexibility Act of 2018
To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to provide for coverage of rural emergency medical access services under the Medicare program, and for other purposes.
Rural Hospital Freedom and Flexibility Act of 2018

item.titleType: (Extracted from GPO) Short Titles as Introduced
item.title: Rural Hospital Freedom and Flexibility Act of 2018

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
